title: From John O'Groats to Land's End; Or, 1372 miles on foot; A book of days and chronicle of adventures by two pedestrians on tour
author: Naylor, John Anderton
snippet: We were served with a prodigious breakfast at the inn to match, as wesupposed, the big appetites prevailing in the North, and then we resumedour walk towards Hawick, meeting on our way the children coming to theschool at Lilliesleaf, some indeed quite a long way from theirdestination.

title: From John O'Groats to Land's End; Or, 1372 miles on foot; A book of days and chronicle of adventures by two pedestrians on tour
author: Naylor, John Anderton
snippet: We were only able to explore the churchyard at Lilliesleaf, as thechurch was not open at that early hour in the morning.

title: From John O'Groats to Land's End; Or, 1372 miles on foot; A book of days and chronicle of adventures by two pedestrians on tour
author: Naylor, John Anderton
snippet: We found that the village was called Lilliesleaf,which we thought a pretty name, though we were informed it had beenspelt in twenty-seven different ways, while the stream we came to in thenight was known by the incongruous name of Ale Water.

title: Rab and His Friends and Other Papers
author: Brown, John
snippet: He was born about 1733, and     after leading a strange life, towards his seventieth year he     stole a horse at Gateshead in the county of Durham, and took     it to Lilliesleaf in Roxburghshire, where he was apprehended     and sent to Durham jail.

title: Rab and His Friends and Other Papers
author: Brown, John

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: full of anecdotes about a friend of his father's, a minister of Lilliesleaf, who reigned for two generations the most popular preacher in Teviotdale ; but I forget the orator's name.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: I think a couple of hours might have passed before he joined us again, which was, rs had been arranged, not far from the village of Lilliesleaf.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Bardolph, bought for me at Lilliesleaf fair by my dear brother Alick, and which I had ridden into the Highlands for health.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: 3 Mr Campbell of Lilliesleaf, who, from his style of preachin-received the sobriquet of " Roarin' Willie," was licensed by thePresbytery of Edinburgh in 175S ; was ordained to the Meeting-House, Berwick in July i759; and inducted to Lilliesleaf inOctober 1760.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: He used totell us that he and his brothers played the samepranks in their early days at his father's manse atLilliesleaf.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: The large curls alluded to, which old JMr Campbell of Lilliesleaf called cannons, were an importantpart of a gentleman's toilet; being carefully concocted at night in paper, and unfolded earlier orlater next day, as occasion required.

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: The entire possessions of the See at the Reformation were the seven baronies and regalities of Glasgow—Carstairs, Stobo, Eddilstoun, Ancrum, Ashkirk, and Lilliesleaf, with the Bishop's Forest and other little things ofcomparatively trifling value in Carrick, Lothian, and elsewhere.
